item.title: Theory: Linear Programming Formulation and Constrained MDPs
item.description: Note: Throughout this section, we assume that \(\ALPHABET X\) and \(\ALPHABET U\) are finite and \(|\ALPHABET X|= n\) and \(|\ALPHABET U| = m\). We know that if \(V \le \mathcal B V\) then \(V \le V^* = \mathcal B V^*\). Thus, \(V^*\) is the “largest” \(V\) that satisfies the constraint \(V \le \mathcal B V\). This constraint can be written as a finite system of linear equations: \[\begin{equation} \label{eq:constaints} V(x) \le c(x,u) + β\sum_{y \in \ALPHABET X} P(y|x,u) V(y), \qquad x \in \ALPHABET X, u \in \ALPHABET U.
